description: I have been working at T-Mobile part-timeÂ (Less than a year)
pros_description: T-Mobile has a pretty good benefit package, good amount of time off for part time employee's and medical coverage is pretty good. The pay package isn't the most competitive in the industry but it does pay better than a lot of electronics/service sales jobs in other categories. Uniforms, Employee discount/phone program.
cons_description: The commission you make all depends on the location you work at make sure your location is busy often, And doesn't have service dead zones in the area. You do a lot of work that you don't get paid for bill payments, troubleshooting, bill explanation, and Data transfers. You can of course solicit anyone who comes in to do any of these things, but often times you end up trying to force products or services on people who either cant afford or don't need them. Stores in my district seem overcrowded with RSA's and that stretches the commission thin. It also seems like most RSA's don't feel job security if you don't hit all of your metrics Mgmt can place you on probation, Fire or forcible transfer you to a less attractive location. While they continue to hire more people on at one location it becomes harder to meet these metrics. Management forces you onto conference calls often with very little warning or planning. unrealistic expectations with some metrics that change often.

description: I have been working at Okta full-timeÂ (More than a year)
pros_description: Remote work options. Free food?
cons_description: When I first joined Okta I was so excited and looked forward to my time and work here but now I can't find a day where I don't feel like absolute crap. Working hard here is not rewarded but having connections and kissing up to people is. There is a huge clique mentality going on and if you don't belong to any cliques expect to not be recognized or rewarded for any hard work you do. The executive team is too busy trying to make sure we look "cool" so I am not really sure where this company is heading. I really regret letting them talk me into joining Okta and leaving my previous company which I actually enjoyed working for.

description: I worked at T-Mobile full-time
pros_description: I really enjoyed working at T-mobile in Kaneohe Hawaii! The environment is exciting and fast paced. A great place to learn new communications and people service skills. I enjoyed working face to face with people and helping them solve their problems or provide solutions to serve. The employee community is friendly and all about teamwork as well as individual growth. As a mom I appreciated that the store hours of operation fit my family lifestyle - not open too early, not closing too late.I enjoyed that there was always an opportunity to learn something new and that we were constantly called to participate in different product or service trainings to grow our knowledge and skill set.
cons_description: I would have said here that the only thing I felt was a con were the uniforms. Before it was an uncomfortable starched collared shirt and black slacks of some sort... now itâs awesomely jeans, sneakers of your choosing, and colorful t-shirts with the T-mobile logo! SO RAD

description: I have been working at T-Mobile full-timeÂ (More than 5 years)
pros_description: 1. Quality, affordable benefits. Health, Vision, Dental, PTO, Maternity/Paternity Leave, help with tuition/child-care, etc.2. Corporate Perks, heavy discounts on Wireless service, Certain Gym franchises, Movie tickets, etc.3. Very Flexible Scheduling with school, children, other employment, etc.4. Sales Incentives, trips, devices, bonuses, etc.5. Diversity; Work with and sell to people from all walks of life, very fun and interesting place to work.6. Opportunities for advancement with simplified hierarchies and substantial increases in salaries as you rise through the ranks.
cons_description: 1. Corporate Politics ("It's not WHAT you know, its WHO you know")2. Annual "Commission Restructures". More and more work, for less and less pay. Changes subject to whatever company focus is at any given time.3. "Don't ask, don't tell" predatory sales practices. Loss prevention/Corporate management generally doesn't get involved unless District/Store Managers are at risk for being "burned" along WITH representatives simply following THEIR instructions.4. "Employee Handbook" (Employee rights/guidelines) is a living, breathing document, "open to interpretation" depending on who's your District/Store managers until and only when you call the Integrity Line/HR anonymously to get concrete yes's and no's with documentations to protect you.

summary: "worst culture - beyond sick to point of incest, dramatic a la GOT"
description: I worked at Pinterest full-timeÂ (Less than a year)
pros_description: aesthetically pleasing coworkers...esp for sf and tech (it's an unspoken core value for the hiring process..)feels like a high school cafeteria - lot's of chattin' and dramarelatively 'open' culture - visibility into product/company/colleagues'embraces' collaboration to a degree - on the surface
cons_description: political af - ties go deep and there's much more than meets the eye (talking bout hr/finance/eng cliques that span across functions and root back to prior companies, relationships...which drives all the unrest, reorgs and other symptoms mentioned in other reviews)passive aggressive - don't for a single second buy into those 'values' - in fact, you'd be better off doing the exact opposite..only don't forget to smile ;]mgmt is scared to take risks - at least your equity vests if you can play the game for a year or two...i mean, double-digit billion dollar valuation stacked with a lot of smart people from previously successful companies...ride that rocket as long as it lasts and avoid drawing attention..lot of latent racism (or perhaps racial tension...discrimination) despite the cheery 'we-are-the-embodiment-of-diversity-and-the-workplace-of-tomorrow-i-mean-look-at-all-this-racial-harmony' messaging and superficial hiring metrics (this is in reference to a google doc where we all were pressured to listed any minorities we may know who'd make the top of recruiting' internal referral lists..that's not at all weird..)sensitive people all around - more about the perception of fitting in (the twisted aforementioned culture) than your quality worktechnical debt
